title: #indigenomics #economicreconciliation #telus #indigenouseconomy #ai‚Ä¶ | Indigenomics
description:
We are deeply grateful to TELUS for their ongoing commitment as our Platinum Multi-Year Events Partner, and for their participation in Indigenomics by DESIGN, SHE, BAY STREET, and the National Indigenomics AI Generative Study this year! Their contributions have been outstanding, and we appreciate how they continue to collaborate and play Indigenomics with us! 

TELUS engaged in various ways this year‚Äîas speakers, vendors, advisors, and hosts. At Indigenomics SHE, Kara Moss, Clinical Supervisor at TELUS Health, shared her insights on the Indigenous Women Leading in Corporate Reconciliation panel. At Indigenomics on BAY STREET, Jesslyn Dymond, Director of AI Governance & Data Ethics, contributed to the panel on AI and the Next Indigenous Economy, while also serving as an advisor on the National Indigenomics AI Generative Study. On Innovation Day, TELUS hosted an Indigenous Placekeeping Tour at TELUS Harbour, showcasing how culturally responsive experiences can be integrated into corporate spaces. Additionally, Amanda Lee, Emily Piccinin, Leila Ashurov, Chloe Santiago, Neil Conti, and Denis Lacasse engaged with conference attendees at DESIGN, SHE, and BAY STREET at the TELUS booth. 

We also want to extend our thanks to the TELUS team members we work with, including Kristen Sandhu, Stephanie Han, Yoelit Lipinsky, PhD, Christy Morgan and Marissa Nobauer ‚Äîwe appreciate you! 

We deeply value TELUS's commitment to playing #Indigenomics and walking with us in advancing economic reconciliation. 

Learn more about this Indigenomics 10 to Watch List company here: https://lnkd.in/gUFSctMY 

#EconomicReconciliation #TELUS #IndigenousEconomy #AI #CorporateReconciliation

title: #indigenomics #tokenomics #blockchain #course | Nationsfirst
description:
We partnered with Sarabloh Technologies LTD. by committing to empowering Indigenous leadership for tomorrow by fostering opportunities in the new digital economy. We believe in equipping individuals with the skills, tools, and innovative tokenomics frameworks needed to lead and shape the technologies of the future, ensuring Indigenous voices are at the forefront of innovation.

Tokenomics represents an opportunity to align traditional Indigenous values, such as reciprocity, sustainability, and community governance, with technology. By leveraging blockchain and decentralized systems, Indigenous communities can create equitable economic models that prioritize long-term prosperity, self-determination, and resource stewardship.

Through our AI, blockchain, and tokenomics training, we‚Äôre addressing historical gaps by providing meaningful pathways for growth, agency, and creativity. This initiative goes beyond education, it‚Äôs about cultivating leaders who can bridge the gap between tradition and technology, driving progress while uplifting Indigenous values and principles.

Together, we are shaping and cultivating a future where Indigenous communities lead with confidence, vision, and impact. 

Special Opportunity for Indigenous Participants:
This course is offered completely FREE for Indigenous participants.

Space is Limited! To ensure a quality learning experience, we are limiting the number of registrations. If interest exceeds our capacity, short interviews will be conducted to select participants who best align with our vision for the program.

Learn more and register: https://lnkd.in/dEvnu6AS

#Indigenomics #Tokenomics #Blockchain #Course

title: #indigenousbusiness #supplierdiversity #csr | Dwayne Good | 17 comments
description:
üö® Is Indigenous Procurement in Australia Facing a Forced Reset?

üåè With diversity & inclusion policies being wound back in the U.S., ripple effects are reaching Australia. As we approach a potential change in Government, what would this mean for supplier diversity and the Indigenous business sector?

üìâ If Indigenous procurement initiatives are scaled back, will Government agencies & corporations reduce their engagement with Indigenous businesses? And if so, is this good or bad?

üìà Over the past five years, Indigenous businesses have grown at an unprecedented rate‚Äî some genuinely Indigenous owned and others not so much. Likewise, more organisations are publicly committing to Indigenous procurement‚Äîranging from those with genuine engagement to others merely fulfilling a checkbox requirement‚úÖ 

üîÑ A Reset is Overdue‚Äîregardless of who is in charge or what policies are in place.

‚öñÔ∏è If supplier diversity loses traction, companies may no longer feel obligated to meet arbitrary spending targets. This could shift the focus from quantity to quality‚Äîwhere Indigenous businesses are valued for their capabilities, innovation & problem-solving skills, not just their ownership status.

‚úÖ Being Indigenous-owned is a powerful differentiator, but it should not be the only one. Long-term success comes from delivering real value, building credibility, & solving genuine business challenges.

ü§ù I don‚Äôt want to see supplier diversity disappear‚ÄîI‚Äôve built meaningful business relationships through existing frameworks. But I do believe the Indigenous business sector is ready for a shakeup‚Äîone that ensures credibility, impact & long-term sustainability.

What do you think needs to happen?

#indigenousbusiness  #supplierdiversity #csr | 17 comments on LinkedIn

title: Indigenous people involvement in business on the rise says author - APTN‚Ä¶ | Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN)
description:
üìà A Tidal Wave of Indigenous Entrepreneurship: Insights from Carol Anne Hilton üåä

Carol Anne Hilton, founder of the Indigenomics Institute, sees a "tidal wave" of Indigenous business growth driven by increased access to capital and improved internet in rural areas. Indigenous women, in particular, are leading the way, starting businesses at five times the national rate and securing roles on corporate boards. Hilton, an award-winning leader from the Nuu chah nulth Nation, sees this growth as a step toward economic reconciliation.

According to Hilton, the rise in Indigenous entrepreneurship is also due to a changing mindset in Canada‚Äôs banking sector. As Indigenous leaders now hold positions on the boards of major financial institutions, new doors are opening for Indigenous business ventures.

Hilton‚Äôs book, Indigenomics: Taking a Seat at the Economic Table, aims to ignite a $100 billion Indigenous economy. This November, the Indigenomics Institute will host a 24-hour Indigenous global economic forum, spotlighting 36 speakers to discuss the future of Indigenous business.

üåç "We‚Äôre building an ecosystem of successful Indigenous business leaders, providing stories and support to inspire others." ‚Äì Carol Anne Hilton

#IndigenousEconomy #Indigenomics #IndigenousEntrepreneurs #EconomicReconciliation #BusinessGrowth

title: #indigenousprosperity #funding #capacitybuilding | Shyra Barberstock, PhD
description:
I stand with NACCA to rally behind the call for increased federal support for Indigenous entrepreneurs.

This past year, I completed my PhD at Queen's University, and my thesis topic was "Indigenous Procurement as a Catalyst for Community Building" (https://lnkd.in/g5uwkivs).

One of the biggest opportunities for Indigenous entrepreneurs right now is procurement. For example, the federal mandate to have a minimum of 5% Indigenous procurement across all federal departments (they are currently doing under 1% Indigenous procurement) provides a significant opportunity for Indigenous entrepreneurs.

However, to take advantage of procurement opportunities, we need to have more scalable Indigenous businesses. How do we get more scalable businesses? Through access to resources, funding, and opportunities. 

This doesn't just extend to Indigenous entrepreneurs‚Äîbusiness support organizations, such as regional IFIs will also need to have increased funding, resources, and capacity to support the influx of scalable Indigenous businesses that require their support.

Let's support NACCA by sharing their message. I personally would like to see more Indigenous businesses taking advantage of the procurement opportunities. This doesn't just benefit Indigenous businesses and communities; it also contributes to Canada's economy.

#IndigenousProsperity #Funding #capacitybuilding

title: #training #mining #esg #empowerment #indigenousbusiness #indigenomics‚Ä¶ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D
description:
Congratulations to the Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) team on winning the Robert R. Hedley Award for Excellence in Social and Environmental Responsibility for its holistic approach to developing a three-year heavy equipment operator program at this years AME Roundup. 

This was an incredible team effort with many partners to make it happen.  The program includes a drivers license program, technical skill development and leadership competencies. It is awesome to watch the program grow and positively impact so many Tahltan members.

The HEO program is a great example that resource projects and Indigenous communities can follow to assist members in gaining mobility, employable skills and meaningful career paths. 

Well done TNDC on continuing to be leaders in the mining space. 

#training #mining #esg #empowerment #indigenousbusiness #indigenomics #gold #copper #community #tahltan #development

title: #indigenomics #reconciliation #telus | Jen Newsted
description:
This year I was gifted ample connection to many fantastic humans who walked alongside the Indigenomics Institute to advance #Indigenomics

A trio of fantastic humans that I want to shine my gratitude on are Tashia Kootenayoo, Stephanie Han and Jen Howton from TELUS. It has been a delight to work with these three, to engage in truthful and curious conversations, and have their support in advancing economic reconciliation. Much gratitude to each of you for how you show up!

Last night I read TELUS' recently released 2023 Indigenous Reconciliation and Connectivity Report and I would encourage folks to do the same.  https://lnkd.in/g3Yuk7xm

I encourage folks to read it for three reasons. The first reason is we, non-Indigenous folks, are grossly overdue on our collective duty to be responding to truth and reconciliation. The second reason is because I have experience both working in telecommunications and leading the Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business Progressive Aboriginal Relations program and I know just how much persistent, intentional effort is required to prioritize reconciliation and shift behaviours inside both giant and small working environments as the barriers to allow change to transpire can and do run deep within each of us as individuals, as a collective and in the colonial system we exist within. 

The third reason is when I read this report I can see that TELUS is both acknowledging they have learning to do AND that they are implementing their learnings from the Indigenous voices they are learning from. This is what reconciliation looks like my friends. 

It looks like Johnny Kelto III being the first voice we hear from followed by acknowledgments of the obligation and responsibility that we non-Indigenous folks/businesses have to ensure there is no longer misappropriation of Indigenous art/artists. 

It looks like bringing our responsibility to be responding to TRC Call to Action 92 to life through prioritized actions that are progressing, not just words in polished corporate copy on websites. 

Give the Indigenous Reconciliation and Connectivity Report a read and invite curiosity in to ask where reconciliation is at with your company/business/self and what will your company/business/self start shifting to ensure you are progressing in persistent, intentional reconcili-ACTION?

No matter how big or small our places of work are reconciliation is required, and it is not difficult. The difficulty, is a barrier that stems from the discomfort of being responsible to acknowledge difficult truths. We must have truth centered in order for reconciliation to happen. So let's get truthful.

#Reconciliation #TELUS

Indigenous Business Report is the official publication and voice of Canadian¬†Council for Indigenous Business (CCIB). Published quarterly, Indigenous Business Report is the largest Indigenous business magazine in Canada. title: #reconciliation #indigenoushistorymonth #indigenomics | Jen Newsted
description:
I had a conversation with a white woman earlier this year about reconciliation and they had shared that if they can't get it right their organization wasn't going to go anywhere near it.

This perspective is one that many individuals and businesses have across the country, this isn't new news.

It is a problematic perspective because it continues to uphold racism and systems of oppression. 

We are each, individually, and collectively, responsible to be righting relations and actively responding to Truth and Reconciliation Call to Action 92. 

It is phenomenally straightforward what we are meant to do, as example:
Listen to Indigenous voices.
Learn from Indigenous voices.
Invest in Indigenous voices.
Support Indigenous voices.
Be led by Indigenous voices.
Believe Indigenous voices.

When I think about folks who say they don't want to get it wrong so they aren't going to do anything, I wonder why they are so comfortable to share their very obvious tells that they haven't taken any of the above straightforward steps, that they aren't interested in taking a look within, and they have no concern about the harms they continue to uphold.

If you just don't know where to start, here is a suggestion, get in the room where Indigenous folks are leading and sharing. 

There is an incredible opportunity in Toronto this November and every sector I have been part of advertising, healthcare, tech, non-profit, tv and film, telecommunications absolutely have no reason to not be in this room. 

Let's get in this room and start shifting our individual and collective accountability into impactful actions that right relations and ensure prosperity for those whose lands we keep saying we live, work and play on.

Let's show up beyond our continued copy and paste acknowledgements of being on stolen land and step into dismantling the barriers we know exist and that we are benefitting from. 

#Reconciliation #IndigenousHistoryMonth #Indigenomics

A human centered collective that values and acknowledges knowledge pathways and awareness of policies that support Indigenous authorities on language, stewardship, and historic knowledge. Community health and wellbeing is a shared experience, sustainability along a path of decoloniality.

title: #landback #ecuador #amazonia #siekopai | Amazon Frontlines
description:
MAJOR WIN for Indigenous #LandBack in the Amazon Rainforest!

The great Naci√≥n Siekopai of #Ecuador, an Indigenous people who have waged a centuries-long battle against conquest, against forced displacement, against forgetting - have finally recovered ownership of their ancestral homeland in the heart of the #amazonia 

The court‚Äôs verdict is in! 104,000 acres will be returned to the #Siekopai people. Their legal victory - which recognizes their collective right to land tenure over their ancestral land - sets a huge precedent for Indigenous nations across Ecuador, and the broader Amazon, to secure permanent legal title over their forests!

After centuries of resistance against conquest, violence and racism, today is a day for rejoicing: Indigenous territories need to be in Indigenous hands!
We are honored to stand with our Siekopai partners in this struggle.

title: #economicreconciliation #indigenousentrepreneurs #decolonizingbusiness‚Ä¶ | Janis Brooks | 16 comments
description:
You can‚Äôt say you support economic reconciliation - and delay payment to your Indigenous contractors. Yet this has happened with three of my clients  in Q1 alone.

A lot of organizations say they support economic reconciliation, but their procurement systems tell a different story.

Because economic reconciliation isn‚Äôt a policy statement. It‚Äôs a practice. And it starts with something as basic and as powerful as paying Indigenous businesses on time.

Of course, all of these clients apologize for late payments.

But when you‚Äôre an Indigenous entrepreneur, an apology doesn‚Äôt cover the mortgage. It doesn‚Äôt ease the stress of running a business in systems that were never designed for you.

What‚Äôs worse? There‚Äôs often no interest, no admin fee, no recourse.

Meanwhile, those same systems expect us to:
- Navigate outdated processes
- Accept inflexible terms
- Be professional and patient, no matter the cost

It‚Äôs not that these organizations don‚Äôt care. It‚Äôs that the systems haven‚Äôt caught up with the values.

And that‚Äôs the heart of it:
Economic reconciliation isn‚Äôt about goodwill. It‚Äôs about structural change.

It means:
- Redesigning procurement to reflect Indigenous values
- Embedding flexibility, reciprocity, and shared accountability
- Understanding that equity isn‚Äôt just about access, it‚Äôs about how systems treat us once we‚Äôre in

If your systems weren‚Äôt built with Indigenous businesses in mind? You can‚Äôt just hope for better results. You have to build better systems.

This is what I help clients do. If you're committed to moving beyond performative action - Let‚Äôs talk about what true economic reconciliation could look like in your procurement practices.

#EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousEntrepreneurs #DecolonizingBusiness #SystemsChange #IndigenousRelations | 16 comments on LinkedIn

title: #indigenousbusiness #buyindigenous #economicreconciliation‚Ä¶ | Steven Vanloffeld
description:
A recent Statistics Canada report is a wake-up call for anyone serious about economic reconciliation. From 2005 to 2018, Indigenous-owned businesses grew by 37%. But despite this growth, major gaps persist:

a) 7.5% less productive
b) 2.7% lower revenue
c) 18.4% more likely to exit the market

These challenges are even greater in rural areas, where many Indigenous businesses operate.Structural barriers‚Äîlimited capital, poor infrastructure, and geographic isolation‚Äîcontinue to hold back Indigenous entrepreneurs.

Resilience isn‚Äôt the issue. Access is.

If we‚Äôre serious about reconciliation, we need targeted investment, bold procurement strategies, and Indigenous-led solutions. That includes our own communities stepping up to buy from Indigenous businesses.

#IndigenousBusiness #BuyIndigenous #EconomicReconciliation #InclusiveEconomy #Procurement

title: #bookserieshighlights #economicreconciliation #undrip #indigenousallyship‚Ä¶ | BST Digital
description:
Building Bridges Through Business: 11 Essential Reads for¬†Meaningful Economic Reconciliation¬†with Indigenous Communities.

As corporations globally seek authentic pathways to advance reconciliation, I‚Äôm honored to introduce¬†Meaningful Economic Reconciliation with Indigenous Peoples¬†‚Äì an 11-volume series designed to equip organizations with actionable strategies rooted in Indigenous wisdom and modern economic frameworks.
Why This Series Matters Now:
With Canada‚Äôs ratification of UNDRIP and growing corporate commitments to TRC Call to Action #92, this collection addresses the urgent need for¬†transformative economic partnerships¬†that center Indigenous self-determination.¬†The series bridges ancestral knowledge with contemporary business practices, offering:
Blueprints for equitable resource-sharing models aligned with UNDRIP Article 39
Case studies of successful Indigenous-industry partnerships from mining to tech
Frameworks for addressing systemic barriers like capital access and infrastructure gaps
Guidance on implementing the The Partnership Accreditation in Indigenous Relations (PAIR) program.
Standout Volumes Include:
"Weaving Two Worlds": Explores reconciling resource development with Indigenous land stewardship through proven relationship-building techniques.
"Upholding Indigenous Economic Relationships"
Critical Insights for Corporate Leaders:
Economic reconciliation boosts project success rates by 40% when Indigenous communities are equity partners. 
78% of infrastructure projects face delays without early Indigenous engagement
Digital adaptations of ceremonial practices increase team cohesion in virtual workspaces. 
"This series doesn‚Äôt just check reconciliation boxes ‚Äì it rewrites the playbook for ethical economic partnerships."
Special Features:
Templates for Indigenous-led impact assessments
Protocols for integrating traditional ecological knowledge
Financial models for community-owned enterprises

title: #indigenousentrepreneur #indigenousbusiness #entrepreneurship #leadership‚Ä¶ | Trent Billette ü™∂
description:
ü™∂ Indigenous Entrepreneur's Code: Building Tomorrow While Honoring Yesterday üåÖ

As a young Indigenous entrepreneur, I've learned that true success comes from blending our ancestral wisdom with modern business practices. Here's our path to success:

Our Sacred Values in Business:

1. üèπ Honor the Path
- Build businesses that serve our communities
- Create sustainable solutions
- Respect traditional knowledge while embracing innovation

2. üåø Growth Mindset
- Every challenge is a teaching
- Success requires both roots and wings
- Learn from elders, innovate for tomorrow

3. üî• Leadership Principles
- Lead with actions, not just words
- Create value for seven generations ahead
- Build bridges between traditional and modern worlds

Modern Business Foundations:

4. üìà Business Essentials
- Know your numbers deeply
- Master digital tools
- Build strong networks
- Create scalable systems

5. ü§ù Community Focus
- Solve real community problems
- Create jobs and opportunities
- Share knowledge freely
- Support other Indigenous entrepreneurs

Daily Practices:

6. üåü Excellence Standards
- Exceed market expectations
- Maintain highest quality
- Innovate continuously
- Stay authentic to our values

üí≠ Remember: Our ancestors were master traders, innovators, and stewards of sustainable business practices. We're not just building businesses - we're continuing a legacy thousands of years in the making.

üå± For Young Indigenous Entrepreneurs:
Your heritage is your superpower. Use it to:
- Create unique value propositions
- Build authentic brands
- Develop sustainable business models
- Connect with global Indigenous networks

üì¢ Call to Action:
- Follow for more Indigenous business insights
- Share your journey using #IndigenousEntrepreneur
- Join our growing community of Indigenous business leaders
- DM for mentorship opportunities

ü§ù Let's Connect:
Building a network of Indigenous entrepreneurs who support each other. Drop a "ü™∂" below if you're part of this journey or want to learn more.

#IndigenousBusiness #Entrepreneurship #Leadership #Innovation #Indigenous #BusinessGrowth #Community #Sustainability

title: #indigenousprosperity #leadership #economicempowerment #innovation‚Ä¶ | Indigenous Prosperity Foundation | 43 comments
description:
Exciting News from the Indigenous Prosperity Foundation! üåü

We are proud to announce Relay Tangie, CPA, FCCA as our new Vice President of Finance & Development!

A Certified Public Accountant (CPA) and Fellow of the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (FCCA, UK), Relay brings more than 20 years of global experience across non-profit and industry sectors and diverse industries. Her expertise in financial strategy, risk management, and community-driven initiatives is deeply informed by her journey through Cameroon, the UK, and Canada. This unique perspective enriches her work, enabling her to drive meaningful impact and create opportunities that empower Indigenous entrepreneurs and communities.

‚ÄúRelay has been instrumental in laying the groundwork for IPF. Her dedication and vision will continue to drive meaningful impact and empower Indigenous entrepreneurs. Together, we‚Äôre building a stronger, more prosperous future.‚Äù - Michelle Okere, CFRE, Executive Director of IPF. 

In her new role, Relay will lead financial sustainability, innovation, and growth to ensure Indigenous women, youth, and early-stage entrepreneurs have the resources they need to thrive.

Join us in celebrating Relay‚Äôs inspiring leadership and vision!

title: #indigenousbusiness #reconciliationinaction‚Ä¶ | Natasha Delany BA, MBA
description:
üö® Unconscious Bias in Business: Are You Holding Indigenous Entrepreneurs Back? üö®

Indigenous business owners bring innovation, resilience, and expertise to every industry. Yet, they often face unconscious biases that limit opportunities and partnerships. Here are some common ones:

‚ùå Assuming Indigenous businesses are less experienced or professional
‚ùå Believing they rely on government handouts instead of being self-sustaining
‚ùå Expecting discounts or free labor in the name of ‚Äúcommunity support‚Äù
‚ùå Only valuing Indigenous businesses for cultural work, not modern industries
‚ùå Questioning Indigenous leadership styles and decision-making
‚ùå Doubting their ability to run long-term, successful businesses

This is something I‚Äôve been reflecting on deeply. Lately, I‚Äôve been presenting a lot on unconscious bias and truth and reconciliation. Through these conversations, I‚Äôve gained a new understanding of what meaningful partnerships with Indigenous businesses look like.

Luckily, we‚Äôve had some amazing clients at Indigenius Projects and Events who have shown me what true reconciliation champions look like. They:

‚úÖ Allow Indigenous companies to lead
‚úÖ Support when there are potential gaps in skill sets
‚úÖ Collaborate in decision-making rather than dictating
‚úÖ Respect Indigenous knowledge systems and ways of doing business
‚úÖ Honor agreements and ensure fair compensation, just like with any other business
‚úÖ Invest in long-term relationships rather than one-time partnerships
‚úÖ Advocate for Indigenous businesses in rooms where we are not present
‚úÖ Recognize that reconciliation is an ongoing process, not a checkbox

This new knowledge, along with the wisdom shared by fellow Indigenous truth and reconciliation speakers, has shifted my perspective and expanded my understanding of what it truly means to partner with an Indigenous company.

Reconciliation isn‚Äôt just about land acknowledgments or one-time contracts‚Äîit‚Äôs about ongoing, respectful, and equitable relationships. Are you ready to be a reconciliation champion?

#IndigenousBusiness #ReconciliationInAction #SupportIndigenousEntrepreneurs #UnconsciousBias #BusinessEquity #TruthAndReconciliation

title: #naturaldiamonds #mining #esg #indigenousbusiness #indigenomics #fashion‚Ä¶ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D | 33 comments
description:
I had the opportunity to present with my fellow panelists at Canada House in London yesterday on the Canadian natural diamond industry.

Some of the key points included:

- The co-management of mining within the NWT between Indigenous groups, government and industry. 

- The best practices of socio-economic agreements and Impact Benefit Agreements that have resulted in meaningful employment, capacity building, economic opportunity and infrastructure. 

- The planned reclamation of the mines before they are even started ensuring that there isn‚Äôt a negative legacy at the end of mine life. 

- How the mining sector has impacted Indigenous communities both positively and negatively. 

- The eye watering experiences of Lily James and her team experiencing -50 for the first time (full disclosure it‚Äôs still darn cold for us northerners as well. 

Thank you for the invite to participate Natural Diamond Council and to Raluca Anghel for organizing. Amazing event.

title: #indigenomics #indigenomics | Jen Newsted
description:
Friends, and especially those in, around, or with connection to Winnipeg- are you registered for the upcoming Indigenomics SHE conference taking place September 23 & 24 yet?

The reason I ask is because I get lots of asks from folks looking for connections or introductions to Indigenous folks that I might know. 

Here's the secret to you skipping the step of having to ask me who I know: Activate your reconciliation commitments by intentionally prioritizing getting yourself into spaces that are Indigenous led so that YOU are in fact doing the work to meet, connect, cultivate relationships with Indigenous leaders and businesses. 

The learning that comes from being in Indigenous led spaces, like the annual events the Indigenomics Institute hosts, are phenomenally rich and imperative for our reconciliation responsibility. But you know this because I have been telling you which is why you are reaching out to me. Remember this is our shared responsibility.

Indigenomics SHE has 40 Indigenous leaders who will share their insights, experiences, challenges, successes in government, law, finance, tech, education, communications, fashion, art, tourism, culinary, corporate canada, entrepreneurism.

The conference will be hosted and emceed again this year by three epic humans who are shining brightly in the image from last year's SHE conference. Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D, CEO and founder of Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre of Indigenomics & the Global Indigenous Technology House, Ashley Richard Director, Indigenous Entrepreneurship University of Waterloo and Diane Roussin BA, BSW, M.S.M. ü¶¶ Project Director, The Winnipeg Boldness Project.

Keynotes are from Laurie Sterritt Managing Partner Pathways Executive Search and Victoria LaBillois, MBA owner of Wejipeg Excavation and founder Eloquent Hostess. 

Additionally, in the room are representatives from Women Entrepreneurship Knowledge Hub (WEKH), TELUS, Vancity, Alliance Trust Company, Calgary, Canada, BFL CANADA, RBC and Scotiabank who are all actively contributing to #Indigenomics as partners and sponsors.

Reconciliation is about relationships and relationships do not happen in documents collecting dust. Please get in this room AND bring your c-suite, your board members, your teams, your clients because my goodness the opportunities that we have to actually show up in reconciliation are abundant - shift status quo behaviour so you stop being the barrier of why you/your company's reconciliation isn't progressing. 

If you can't physically be there you can still contribute by committing to an Accessibility package that will allow for Indigenous folks to participate on your behalf. This is also how we start to cultivate relationships. 

Finally, here's another super simple way to action reconciliation: Copy the link below and put it in your newsletters. It isn't difficult friends, unless we make it. 

I hope I see you in Winnipeg for #Indigenomics

https://lnkd.in/gkG43kUw

title: #indigenomics #gcoi #indigenousworldview #indigenouseconomy‚Ä¶ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D
description:
Indigenomics  NOW draws inspiration from the powerful Nuu-chah-nulth concept of ‚Äútsawalk," which translates to "one." This profound principle reminds us that all living beings, from humans and animals to the very plants that sustain us, are fundamentally interconnected, forming a single, harmonious whole.

Within the framework of Indigenomics, "tsawalk" becomes a guiding light, to acknowledge the intrinsic interconnectedness of our economic systems with the natural world. Indigenomics NOW is designed to reflect the natural world and serves to advance an economic narrative that is shaped by the natural world.

Indigenomics NOW serves as a powerful platform to translate this philosophy into action. November 14th ,2024. Registration opens soon.


Stay informed about our latest advancements by subscribing to the Global Centre of Indigenomics newsletter.
https://tr.ee/QBkuLfadVq

I‚Äôm positive that my passion for uplifting Native voices and empowering Native communities is my life‚Äôs purpose. 

This past 18 months, my ‚Äúwork‚Äù has taken me to international spaces to advocate for Indigenous stewardship over our traditional Tribal homelands and its biodiversity. The culmination of these efforts transpired last night when President Joe Biden signed proclamations to designate Chuckwalla and S√°tt√≠tla landscapes as National Monuments. Chuckwalla has a trail system that is 1 part of a 3-part trail system that is incredibly sacred to my Tribe, the Ft. Yuma Quechan Tribe, and our sister Tribes. I am so honored to have played a small role in this effort. Iwa ax√≥t then tha (deepest form of gratitude) to everyone involved. This will go down as a moment in history where Tribes collectively led #LANDBACK and I promise you, it‚Äôs not the last. Next up, the last piece of the puzzle: Kw‚Äôts√°n National Monument. title: #indigenouspeoplesday #landback #spaceenvironmentalism‚Ä¶ | Moriba Jah
description:
On this #IndigenousPeoplesDay, let‚Äôs recognize that our presence here is to be a collaborative part of nature. We are uniquely equipped to be stewards, and this special role is what we are continually being entrusted with.

We are blessed to have role models in this regard. Indigenous communities have been stewards of this planet for millennia, and their knowledge - traditional ecological knowledge is essential to halting our path to self-extinction. 

Honoring them means more than acknowledging their wisdom; it means accepting our intergenerational contract of stewardship with the planet and beyond.

Here are 3 ways to be a true ally to Indigenous peoples:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Center Their Voices: Follow and amplify Indigenous-led platforms like Indigenous Climate Action and Nia Tero. These organizations are at the forefront of environmental and cultural preservation, sharing stories that the world needs to hear.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Support Indigenous Sovereignty: Advocate for land rights and protections with groups by reading up on hashtags like #LandBack and following groups like Honor The Earth who fight tirelessly for the respect of Indigenous land and self-determination.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Invest in Their Movements: Donate or partner with organizations like Seeding Sovereignty and IllumiNative Org, which provide resources and visibility to Indigenous-led projects across environmental, social, and cultural arenas.

This isn‚Äôt just a day for reflection‚Äîit‚Äôs a call to action! For the Earth, for honoring our original oath, and for all future generations. 

Level ‚¨ÜÔ∏è! ü§ôüèæ
#SpaceEnvironmentalism #celestialstewardship

title: #blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics | Nationsfirst
description:
The Indian Act, established in 1876 by the Canadian government, was not designed to honor or leverage the economic wealth of Indigenous peoples. Instead, it was primarily set up as a tool for assimilation and control, imposing European governance structures, restricting Indigenous rights, and undermining traditional economic and social systems. This Act centralized decision-making by Canada, disempowering Indigenous communities and disconnecting them from their traditional governance and economic practices, which were deeply intertwined with their cultural and spiritual beliefs. 

To truly move towards self-determination, Indigenous communities may need to unlearn the systems imposed by the Indian Act and re-engage with their traditional ways. This involves revitalizing Indigenous legal systems and cultural practices and may include adopting modern technologies such as blockchain. Utilizing blockchain could provide transparent and secure methods for managing community resources and transactions, potentially even supporting the creation of a value-based currency that reflects Indigenous values and priorities. Such steps are fundamental in re-establishing Indigenous economic systems and governance structures on their terms and according to their traditional laws and practices.

#blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics

title: #landback | NDN Collective
description:
NDN Collective, through its community development arm NDN Holdings, has returned two acres of ancestral land along Eyak Lake to the Eyak people in Alaska, marking a historic #LANDBACK deal with the Eyak Community Land Trust that paves the way for cultural revival, ecological education, and the raising of the first sacred totem pole in over 150 years. This groundbreaking effort exemplifies the power of Indigenous-led initiatives to reclaim sacred lands and create spaces for healing, restoration, and generations of cultural revitalization.

title: #tribalsovereignty #landback | Kevin Washburn | 22 comments
description:
On December 18, 2014, the Obama-Biden Administration removed "the Alaska exception" to the land-into-trust regulations. This rule cleared the way to create new Indian reservations in Alaska. See https://lnkd.in/ggiTfzxf  

It was one of the proudest moments of my life.

Changing federal Indian policy is not easy. It took more than eight years and dueling solicitor's opinions for the law to be applied successfully, but the good news is that the Biden-Harris Administration is about to take the first new parcel of land in Alaska into trust. https://lnkd.in/gXvmsMT4 

Thank to ASIA Bryan Newland and Solicitor Bob Anderson for getting the first Alaska trust land acquisition across the finish line.  

Thank you, Heather Miller, for turning the United States around on this issue. 

And congratulations to the Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska for doing the hard work to expand tribal sovereignty!

#tribalsovereignty #landback     | 22 comments on LinkedIn

title: #nahm #nativeamericanheritagemonth #landback #manifestdestiny‚Ä¶ | Native Americans in Philanthropy | 15 comments
description:
Land Back is not merely a campaign slogan or social justice hashtag; it is a powerful movement that is actively returning millions of acres back into Native hands‚Äîthe reversal of manifest destiny.

Journalist Kalen Goodluck (Din√©, Mandan, Hidatsa, and Tsimshian), author of the article, ‚ÄúHow the Land Back Movement Is Unraveling Manifest Destiny‚Äù, goes into great detail about recent wins, the long and painful history of Native land theft, the hurdles preventing our communities from acquiring land, the cultural significance of reclaiming stolen land, and the spirit of the phrase itself.

‚ÄúThanks to the Land Back movement, though, Indigenous peoples are weaving their own destiny. Lands once torn at the seams are being mended by the Tribes via a patchwork of efforts. Manifest Destiny is unraveling as a vision of Indian justice unfolds.‚Äù ‚ÄîKalen Goodluck

Read the full article to learn more ‚û°Ô∏è https://lnkd.in/eXeca6-c

#NAHM #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth #LandBack #ManifestDestiny #NativeAmerican #Indigenous #Native #WeAreIndigenous | 15 comments on LinkedIn

title: Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation | Deloitte Canada | Anthony Viel
description:
In 2020, the Canadian government announced their intention to acknowledge the hardships and injustices #Indigenous communities have faced at the hands of former Canadian leaders. A Truth and Reconciliation Day was announced, and tomorrow we commemorate the second annual recognition of the ongoing need for reconciliation in this country.
¬†
When it comes to #reconciliation, making long-term progress demands that our actions be grounded in accountability and transparency. Deloitte's Reconciliation Action Plan year-two update report: Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation, shares some of the ongoing efforts we have made to fund Indigenous groups and their allies, adapt our systems, and provide resources for our employees to educate themselves about Indigenous culture. The road to reconciliation is long and, at times, challenging, but we continue to strive toward being better listeners and doing our part in contributing to reconciliation efforts. 
¬†
In honour of this important day, we have given our people tomorrow off in the hopes they will use this time to reflect and continue to educate themselves ‚Äì be it attending a workshop, reading a book from an Indigenous author, donating to a local Indigenous-run charity, or learning more about the rich culture and history of Indigenous peoples. On this day, and throughout the year, our primary focus must be to listen, learn, and do our part.¬†We hope our actions will serve as inspiration for others to do the same.

https://lnkd.in/gVcfsg7U

title: #indigenousprosperity #executivedirector #empowerment‚Ä¶ | NACCA
description:
The Indigenous Prosperity Foundation (IPF), an independent charitable organization established by NACCA and Indigenous Financial Institutions across Canada, is seeking an exceptional candidate to fill the role of inaugural Executive Director!

At IPF, our mission centres on fostering success and empowerment among underserved Indigenous women, youth, and early-stage entrepreneurs across Canada. We will achieve this by providing comprehensive support, including training, mentorship, digital access, and seed grants. Our aim is to ensure accessibility and equity while building capacity within the Indigenous economic development ecosystem.

We are searching for an individual with proven executive-level experience, a track record of impactful leadership, and a deep commitment to our mission. If you are, or you know, someone who embodies these qualities and is ready to make a significant difference, we encourage you to share this opportunity with them.

For more information about this esteemed position and to learn more about the vital work we do at IPF, please visit our website at https://lnkd.in/gMGEw3vQ.

Join us as we embark on a journey to empower Indigenous communities and entrepreneurs across Canada. 

#IndigenousProsperity #ExecutiveDirector #Empowerment #IndigenousEntrepreneurs #MakeADifference

title: #cheekbone #indigenomics #yukonsoaps #ravenreads #indigenousbox‚Ä¶ | June Anthony-Reeves
description:
PEER MENTORING IN BUSINESS!

I've had the honor of learning from very strong and successful women and men in business!  

It didn't take me long to realize that I could not and should not attempt to manage, operate or grow my business on my own!  I needed to learn from the business women and men who had done this before me!  I learned very quickly that we were not in competition, and so many successful business people were willing to help me grow my business!

I learned from several business books published by successful business women and I shamelessly support the writings and teachings from  Arlene Dickinson, Venture Communications.  I had chats with the successful beauty brand #Cheekbone creator, Jen Harper, and successful female leaders from #indigenomics, Carol Anne Hilton; #yukonsoaps, #RavenReads,#Indigenousbox, #BearsLairTV creator Geena Jackson and so many more peer mentors and successful business people across Canada.  I am so grateful!!

I also have a business coach who helps me  to  find resources for the growth  and management of my business.  

I encourage everyone to find their peer mentors in business!  

#peers #businessmentors #businessincanada #businessmanagement #businessbooks #businesssuccess

NACCA is excited to announce Stan Wesley as our host for the 2024 Indigenous Prosperity Forum to be held on May 8 & 9 at the Hilton Lac Leamy in Gatineau.

For over 30 years, Stan has engaged and entertained audiences with his unique style of presentations, keynotes, emcee and facilitation services. Working at the local, regional, provincial and national levels, he speaks on a variety of issues with a focus on celebrating success and advancing good, healthy relations among Indigenous and non-Indigenous peoples. With his high-energy, sincere, professional approach, he is considered by many to be one of the top speakers in the country today. Stan currently lives in Six Nations Territory with his beautiful wife, Mandy, and their incredible daughters Maya and Tenona.

description:
The Giant Mine project reclamation project just outside of Yellowknife, NWT is starting to ramp up. Over the next 2 years the industrial buildings onsite will be demoed and materials disposed of. 

The Tlicho Investment Corporation & Group of Companies has partnererd with True North Environmental to provide the necessary labour.  The TIC team will be providing recruitment and information sessions for the project!

Join us for an upcoming session in your community:


 *   Behchoko Culture Centre (aka Behchoko Presence Office): Sunday, February 23, 1-4 pm
 *   Whati Culture Centre: Monday, February 24, 4-7:30 pm
 *   Yellowknife TIC Office/Boardroom: Tuesday, February 25,  5-8 pm

Here's what you can expect at each location:

Behchok«´ÃÄ:
1-2 pm - Doors Open/Welcome
2-3 pm - Presentation/Employment Opportunities
3-4 pm - Employment Application Support

What√¨:

title: #landback #landback #landback #landback | Warƒ´Nkwƒ´ Flores
description:
A Call for Contributions for a Special Issue of the Parks Stewardship Forum on #LANDBACK through Rematriation. It provides a platform for Indigenous Peoples to share their experiences and Knowledge related to #LANDBACK and Rematriation.

We invite contributions in various formats, including academic manuscripts, stories, poems, songs, artwork, and photo essays.

Important Dates:
Abstracts (up to 400 words) due: September 1, 2024
Decision notifications: October 1, 2024
Full submissions due: February 1, 2025
Submission Details:

‚úçüèΩ Email abstracts, author listings, and positionality statements to Lara Jacobs at jacob475@msu.edu by September 1, 2024.
üôåüèΩ We welcome Indigenous Youth, Elders, community members, and academic contributions.
Submissions can be in Indigenous languages or English.
üîÑ Contributors will be compensated, with the exact amount determined later by our fundraising efforts. (If you or your organization would like to help fund this project, please contact us!)

The Parks Stewardship Forum is an open-access journal. For more information, visit the PSF website. https://lnkd.in/eqGrzZEx

Topics for Consideration:
Below, we provide a listing of topic areas to consider for proposals. Still, each topic area should also be connected to Rematriation and #LANDBACK in the context of the world‚Äôs parks, protected areas, cultural sites, and other forms of place-based conservation. 

- Indigenous-led land, water, wildlife, and plant management paradigms and models
- Co-equity-based land, water, wildlife, and plant management paradigms and models.
- The practical implications of #LANDBACK in the U.S. (e.g., case studies from Australia or Canada, examples from other areas around the world, and/or theoretical implications)
- Indigenous resistance, activism, environmental justice, and social movements
- Indigenous Arts, Artists, and Creative Expressions
- Colonization, Decolonization, Indigenizing, and Survivance
- Indigenous food sovereignty
- Indigenous histories and historiography
- Preserving Indigeneity, place-based Peoples, and place-based conservation efforts¬†
- Reclamation of Indigenous Languages and Place Names¬†
- Indigenous Futurities and Feminisms
- Indigenous Methodologies
- Place-Based Museum and Archival Reclamation¬†
- Tribal Historic Preservation Work
- Cultural and Land Resource Management
- Good Fire (Indigenous cultural fire reclamation and land restoration)¬†
- Indigenous Law, Sovereignty, Autonomy, and Governance

title: #mining #exploration #indigenousbusiness #indigenomics #esg #community‚Ä¶ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D
description:
Finishing up a busy week at the Prospectors and Development Association of Canada (PDAC) conference in Toronto. Had the opportunity to connect with lots of colleagues while proudly representing Tlicho Investment Corporation & Group of Companies with members of the team and Tlicho leadership. 

Several of us sat down on a panel discussing a decarbonized mining world. Some great examples from across the North for both active and exploration mining project all of which had significant Indigenous involvement. 

It was announced that I have joined the board for Kingfisher Metals Corp.  Excited to join Dustin Perry, P.Geo. and the team in their journey to develop the next world class properties in the golden triangle.  They have a great vision and are focused on creating value for the Tahltan nation on the lands that they operate on. 

Hope everyone had an excellent PDAC as well!!!

title: #indigenousentrepreneur #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness‚Ä¶ | Trent Billette ü™∂
description:
üìö My Journey as an Indigenous Entrepreneur: From Reading to Building a Knowledge Library üìö

When I first set out on this journey, I had a simple goal: read one book a month to sharpen my skills as an entrepreneur. But somewhere along the way, I realized this was bigger than just reading. I wasn‚Äôt just consuming knowledge‚ÄîI was collecting it, curating it, and applying it to build something greater: Indigpreneur.

As Indigenous people, our knowledge has always been passed down through stories, teachings, and lived experience. Today, books have become another way for me to learn from those who came before us‚Äîleaders, thinkers, and changemakers who have built businesses, disrupted industries, and reshaped economies.

üìñ Starting with ‚ÄúIndigenomics: Taking a Seat at the Economic Table‚Äù by Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D 

This book isn‚Äôt just a read‚Äîit‚Äôs a blueprint. Hilton lays out how Indigenous people can reclaim economic power, create wealth in our communities, and move beyond surviving to thriving in business. It‚Äôs a powerful reminder that we don‚Äôt need to fit into existing systems‚Äîwe can build our own.

üöÄ How Indigpreneur Will Implement These Teachings:

‚úÖ Building Indigenous-Led Networks: Indigenomics highlights the need for strong Indigenous business ecosystems. Through Indigpreneur, I‚Äôm focused on creating a network where Indigenous entrepreneurs collaborate, share resources, and grow together.

‚úÖ Creating Wealth, Not Just Jobs: Hilton talks about the importance of ownership. Indigpreneur isn‚Äôt just about helping Indigenous businesses start‚Äîit‚Äôs about helping them scale, sustain, and create long-term wealth in our communities.

‚úÖ Elevating Indigenous Innovation: Indigenous knowledge and ways of doing business are an advantage, not a limitation. I want Indigpreneur to champion modern Indigenous business models‚Äîones rooted in our values, but thriving in today‚Äôs economy.

üì¢ This isn‚Äôt just about me‚Äîit‚Äôs about all of us. If you‚Äôre an Indigenous entrepreneur, business leader, or changemaker, let‚Äôs connect and share knowledge.

üèÜ Join the Indigenous Entrepreneur Roundtable

At the end of this month, I‚Äôm hosting a roundtable discussion where we‚Äôll explore how we can take action on these ideas, share insights, and connect as Indigenous entrepreneurs.

üîó Register here: https://lnkd.in/g-EhkV57

üìñ What books have shaped your mindset? How do you see Indigenous business evolving? Let‚Äôs start a conversation in the comments!

#IndigenousEntrepreneur #Indigenomics #IndigenousBusiness #ReclaimingEconomy #LifelongLearning #EntrepreneurshipJourney #IndigenousExcellence #Indigpreneur

title: #indigenousbusiness #gratitude | Tabatha Bull ICD.D | 70 comments
description:
Five Years!! 
Five years ago today, I stepped into this role in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic  - a time of immense uncertainty for all of us. The early days of the pandemic proved just how important our work is - ensuring Indigenous businesses have the support, resources, and opportunities they need to thrive. Despite the challenges, I was fortunate to have a dedicated team committed to supporting Indigenous entrepreneurs and communities. Together, we adapted, redefined how we worked, and most importantly ensured that family and mental health remained a top priority. 

Since then, we have seen incredible growth, with CCIB's membership expanding from 1,000 to 2,700 strong. Introducing new programs, advocating for change and constantly improving our supports. This reflects not only the strength and resilience of Indigenous businesses but also the increasing recognition of the importance of Indigenous procurement and economic empowerment.

Today, we find ourselves in another period of uncertainty, and just as we were then, CCIB will be here stronger than ever - advocating, supporting, and ensuring Indigenous businesses continue to grow and succeed.

On a personal level, these past five years have been filled with both joy and challenges. I've watched my sons grow into young men and navigated family loss and illness, all while spending more time traveling to attend important events. ¬†I am grateful for every experience, but for those who think it is all glamourous it has often meant I have missed moments at home. Through it all, I have been deeply grateful for the support of my husband and kids, who have stood by me every step of the way.

I feel very blessed for all of the opportunities of growth that this journey has provided and honoured by the recognition this role has brought. Most importantly, I am so thankful for everyone who has been part of this journey our team, ¬†members, partners, and friends. Your commitment and belief in our work continue to inspire me every day. 

Chi miigwetch for walking this path with me. Here's to the next chapter!

#IndigenousBusiness #Gratitude Canadian Council for Indigenous Business | 70 comments on LinkedIn

title: #indigenomics #economicreconciliation #indigenousleadership‚Ä¶ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D
description:
"It‚Äôs time for the fire of Indigenous economic justice to transform how we build and share wealth. Together, we are building an economy rooted in our traditions, knowledge, and sovereignty."

As Indigenous peoples, we are not just participants in the economy; we are architects of a system that reflects our interconnectedness, sustainability, and collective prosperity. Economic justice means recognizing our inherent rights, fostering economic reconciliation, and creating pathways for economic sovereignty that benefit all.

We are witnessing a transformative era where Indigenous businesses, entrepreneurs, and nations are reclaiming their rightful place at the economic table. The future is being shaped by Indigenous leadership, collaborative partnerships, and a vision that respects the land, our values, and our people.

Let‚Äôs continue to fuel this momentum. Who wants to play Indigenomics?
Email info@indigenomics.com for sponsorship opportunities.

#Indigenomics #EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousLeadership #IndigenousWealth #EconomicJustice #Sovereignty #FutureOfIndigenousEconomies #TogetherWeThrive

title: #indigenousyouth #indigenousprosperity #bawaadanconsulting | NACCA | 16 comments
description:
Chris Lefebvre, the founder and Principal of Bawaadan Consulting Inc., a 100% First Nation owned consultancy specializing in Indigenous relations, is our newest Indigenous Youth Council Member.

With over 15 years of experience, Chris has worked extensively with Indigenous communities in various capacities, including roles at Shell Canada, Scotiabank, Mattagami First Nation, and as the head of business development for the Mississaugas of the Credit First Nation.

Bawaadan Consulting focuses on Indigenous participation plans, engagement, and economic development, bringing corporate Canada and Indigenous communities together for mutual growth and success. Chris's expertise and commitment to bridging the gap between the two sectors make him a valuable addition to our council.

As a member of our National Indigenous Youth Business Advisory Council, Chris will provide invaluable insight and guidance to support other Indigenous youth.

Welcome, Chris! We're excited to have you on board.

#IndigenousYouth #IndigenousProsperity #BawaadanConsulting | 16 comments on LinkedIn

title: #indigenousentrepreneur #reconciliationinaction #forusbyus‚Ä¶ | Stan Knight
description:
Happy Friday, my friends ‚Äî we‚Äôve made it through another week and earned our weekend.

Here‚Äôs the latest from my Indigenous Entrepreneurial Journey:
‚úÖ 34 meetings this week ‚Äî a personal record!
- 6 consultants ‚Äî all thoughtful and productive conversations
- 2 modular housing companies ‚Äî interesting, but not quite the right fit for me
- 11 ‚Äútire kickers‚Äù ‚Äî folks mostly looking to sell something
- 15 fantastic new friends and allies ‚Äî people I genuinely look forward to working with again

I‚Äôm incredibly grateful for the chance to connect with so many people this week. Every conversation adds to the bigger picture, and I‚Äôm especially encouraged by the number of non-Indigenous allies I met who are doing this work with respect, honesty, and real heart.

It‚Äôs helped restore some of the hope I‚Äôve lost over the years when it comes to meaningful reconciliation (not all of it ‚Äî policing will do that to you). But these connections matter, and they move us forward.

Wishing you all a restful weekend. I'm already looking forward to what next week brings.

#IndigenousEntrepreneur #ReconciliationInAction #ForUsByUs #IndigenousHousing #CommunityDriven #StrongerTogether #AllyshipMatters #EntrepreneurJourney #IndigenousInnovation #CapacityBuilding

title: #indigenousentrepreneur #indigenouswomenrise #indigenousbusiness | Natasha Delany BA, MBA
description:
Yesterday, I had lunch with an amazing business woman about value. We discussed how many entrepreneurs struggle to see the true value they create for others. Many view their products or services as singular, not realizing that what they truly offer is multidimensional and, in many ways, invaluable. I used to think this way too. As an event manager specializing in Indigenous experiences, I once felt that all I was doing was planning events. It wasn‚Äôt until later that I saw the deeper value I was creating‚Äînot just for my corporate clients but also for Indigenous entertainers, vendors, entrepreneurs, Elders, and every participant we serve at our events.

I was impacting the next generation of Indigenous youth attending conferences and contributing to the Indigenous economy. I was providing opportunities that some might say are priceless, with no cost that could truly capture the value my company was creating. Imagine how I felt when I realized this. The value my company was generating‚Äîand the value I brought with my skills, life experience, and knowledge‚Äîhelped me understand the broader economic impact of my services.

I was no longer ‚Äòjust an event planner.‚Äô This unique awareness is something I teach my Diamonds Mastermind students as well. I guide them to see that they are not simply selling a product or service‚Äîthey are offering so much more. I help them uncover the value in their business and within themselves. Only when we recognize and charge our true worth can we fully serve those we aim to support. This alignment, this balance‚Äîthe yin and yang‚Äîcreates and sustains the flow of life.

#indigenousentrepreneur #indigenouswomenrise #indigenousbusiness

title: TELUS is proud to partner with the Indigenomics Institute, embracing our‚Ä¶ | Shazia Sobani
description:
TELUS is proud to partner with the Indigenomics Institute, embracing our shared vision that, together with Indigenous Peoples, we can incorporate Indigenous perspectives into how the economy functions and benefits all people in Canada. Our commitment to reconciliation goes beyond words - it's about action. This includes ensuring that Indigenous experts, leaders, and organizations have the platform to share their insights and expertise, which is why we are proud to be a multi-year event partner with the Indigenomics Institute. 

Registration for the Indigenomics by Design conference is now open! For those located in and near Saskatoon, SK, we warmly invite you to join this transformative event for an unparalleled opportunity to learn from visionaries like Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D, who are at the forefront of guiding corporate Canada towards viewing the economy through an Indigenous lens.

description:
It is so important to highlight people in our lives who demonstrate allyship.¬† These souls care about and understand the barriers, inequities and injustice perpetuated on Indigenous peoples.¬† I would like to recognize NACCA CSO Gerry Huebner for his unrelenting passion and contribution to the AFI network. 
We worked together 20 years ago with Aboriginal Business Canada and now we work together administering and growing this program and network. Over the last number of years we introduced a market ready Indigenous Growth Fund, a Women's program, renewed AEP support, rolled out Covid business supports, solidified the Indigenous Prosperity Forum¬† (one of the most impactful events in Canada), added 500M in programming - which will lead to positive socioeconomic impacts for our communities. One dollar added, in turn multiplies back into the whole economy.¬† Thank you Gerry, Thank you to your powerhouse of a fianc√© Kim, and the entire NACCA team, network and board for your contribution to bettering society as a whole and making Indigenous Prosperity a reality. title: #indigenousentrepreneurship #indigenous #entrepreneurship #innovation‚Ä¶ | Trent Billette ü™∂
description:
ü™∂ Embracing Indigenous Innovation: Where Traditional Wisdom Meets Modern Enterprise 

As an Indigenous entrepreneur, I've witnessed firsthand the transformative power of combining our ancestral knowledge with contemporary business practices. Our communities have always been innovators, traders, and stewards of sustainable enterprise.

Today, I'm excited to share why Indigenous entrepreneurship isn't just about business‚Äîit's about:

‚ú® Preserving Cultural Legacy
‚Ä¢ Creating enterprises that honor our traditions
‚Ä¢ Sharing our stories through ethical commerce
‚Ä¢ Building sustainable models that respect Mother Earth

üí´ Community Empowerment
‚Ä¢ Generating opportunities for future generations
‚Ä¢ Reinvesting in Indigenous communities
‚Ä¢ Fostering economic sovereignty

üåü Innovative Solutions
‚Ä¢ Blending traditional wisdom with modern technology
‚Ä¢ Creating unique products and services
‚Ä¢ Leading in sustainable business practices

To my fellow Indigenous entrepreneurs: Your voice matters. Your innovations matter. Your businesses matter. We're not just building companies‚Äîwe're creating legacies that honor our ancestors while paving the way for our children.

To allies and partners: Let's collaborate to create an inclusive economy that celebrates Indigenous innovation and entrepreneurship. Together, we can build a future where Indigenous business leadership thrives.

#IndigenousEntrepreneurship #Indigenous #Entrepreneurship #Innovation #BusinessLeadership #EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousBusiness #Sustainability

title: #indigenomics #reconciliation #legacywork #matriarchmoves‚Ä¶ | Tanya Tourangeau | 10 comments
description:
At the Indigenomics Impact Conference in Vancouver, I stood on the main stage and offered a Sacred Prayer.

I read from my upcoming book‚Äîa letter written to my Granddaughter to be opened in the year 2059, when she turns 50.

And today, I‚Äôm sharing a short video of that reading here with you.

It is a prayer.
It is a vision.
It is a legacy.

A legacy for a world I dreamed I was building for her.
A world where I walked through fires so she can walk through open doors.
A world where my ‚ÄúGiving-Kindness-to-Each-Other‚Äù theory isn‚Äôt just imagined‚Äîbut lived.

This post is a brief inside view of the direction my book is taking‚Äîand the heart of my work as a Reconciliation Strategist.

My deepest hope is that when she reads this in 2059, she‚Äîand all of us‚Äîare living that dream.

#Indigenomics #Reconciliation #LegacyWork #MatriarchMoves #GivingKindnessToEachOther #IndigenousLeadership #2059Vision #TruthToTransformation #FutureGenerations | 10 comments on LinkedIn

Illinois Governor JB Pritzker signed a law transferring an entire state park to the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation, restoring a portion of their stolen land. This action comes nearly a year after the Prairie Band Potawatomi became the first federally recognized Tribal Nation in Illinois‚Äîone of 15 states previously without a federally recognized tribe. title: #forests #landback #women | Rights and Resources Initiative
description:
Who owns the world‚Äôs forests?
¬†
RRI‚Äôs new Tenure Tool helps researchers, academics, activists, community leaders and the general public answer this and other questions on forest tenure with data from 58 countries making up nearly 92% of the world‚Äôs #forests.
¬†
The Tenure Tool is designed to make global, regional and country-level data accessible and comprehensible. Despite significant gains in land rights reforms since 2002, many obstacles remain, and communities continue to challenge governments and private sector actors to win their forests and #LandBack.
¬†
The Tenure Tool even looks at the forest rights of #women and assesses the extent to which the legal frameworks of 30 low- and middle-income countries recognize Indigenous, Afro-descendant, and community women‚Äôs rights to community forests.

Browse the data üëáüèæ

title: #indigenomics #indigenouseconomy #economicreconciliation | Indigenomics
description:
Only 10 Days away! Are you registered for Indigenomics Design- Indigenous Wealth Dynamics?

Breakout speakers Thomas Benjoe, OneHoop and Joshua A. , Raven Indigenous Capital Partners, will discuss "Building Indigenous-Led Capital," sharing insights on economic sovereignty and Indigenous leadership. This is what Indigenomics means to them;

"Indigenomics, to me, represents a commitment to empowering Indigenous communities through financing, sustainable technology, and innovation. It involves weaving traditional Indigenous values into investment practices, emphasizing collaboration and community-focused development in the tech sector." Josh Alook

'For too long our peoples livelihood have been associated with poverty but poverty was not created by poor people. It is created by the economic and social systems that we have designed for ourselves, the institutions and concepts that make up these systems are the result of decision made by human beings. As we create them, so we can change them. Through Indigenomics we will change the institutions and concepts to see our people prosper in business and economics." Thomas Benjoe

Don't miss this chance to engage with leaders in Indigenous economic design. Final call for registration! https://lnkd.in/geyuwQtG

#Indigenomics #IndigenousEconomy #EconomicReconciliation

title: #indigenomics #indigenouspower | Katie Fitzmaurice
description:
‚ÄúWe have described for you a mountain.
We have shown you the path to the top.
We call upon you to do the climbing.‚Äù
~ Chief Commissioner Murray Sinclair
TRC Commission

The #Indigenomics by Design conference has served to inspire, educate, and humble me. The thought leaders, change agents, and community builders that have presented and participated in the event have made clear what #indigenouspower is and the impact of that power and success.

Some sources of inspiration (and this is not at all comprehensive so I encourage future attendance at the event!) include:

üîãIndigenous People‚Äôs are leading the clean energy transition. 
‚ñ´Ô∏è‚ÄùIndigenous inclusion means a just transition to a clean energy future.‚Äù ~ Carol Anne Hilton, MBA 
‚ñ´Ô∏è Research from a 2020 Indigenous Clean Energy Social Enterprise report identified 197  Canadian companies in the clean energy sector.
‚ñ´Ô∏è Research from Chris Henderson was cited, noting ‚ÄúIndigenous communities are the third largest owners of clean energy companies in Canada.‚Äù

üß≠ The theory of change must chart the straightest line between the current and future state. This must involve meaningful and deep consideration of what economic reconciliation means and a commitment and plan to advance it. Without this understanding, there is a risk of advancing projects merely for marketing purposes, missing true impact. 
‚ñ´Ô∏è Recommended reading: Raven Impact Measurement Framework (RIM)
‚û°Ô∏è https://lnkd.in/g-jhVn4Q by Raven Indigenous Capital Partners. 

ü§ù Partnerships are key to advancing economic development and building indigenous prosperity.

Further reflections of the learnings of today and yesterday are required. Deepest gratitude to all in the room and event organizers for creating this space and opportunity.

Celebrating Indigenomics Scholarship Recipient: Lance Black! 

We are thrilled to introduce Lance B., a recipient of the 2024 Indigenomics Scholarship. Lance Black is Anicinape from Apitipi Anicinapek Nation in Ontario. He is the Director of Negotiations and Contract Management for his Nation and an MBA candidate at Ivey Business School. Lance represents his community in mining negotiations while also leading Apitipi Resources Inc. as President. title: #indigenousbusiness #economicgrowth #indigenomics #forwardsummit‚Ä¶ | RedFeather Strategies
description:
Indigenous Business Growth: A Catalyst for Economic Change in Canada

Indigenous businesses are rapidly transforming Canada's economy, with over 50,000 Indigenous-owned enterprises across various sectors. This growth is not just about economic prosperity but also about self-determination, reconciliation, and strengthening Indigenous leadership.

Initiatives like the Indigenomics movement and Forward Summit are vital in supporting Indigenous entrepreneurs. Indigenomics envisions a $100 billion Indigenous economy built on innovation and investment, benefiting both Indigenous communities and the broader Canadian economy.

Despite challenges such as global trade tensions and political uncertainty, Indigenous businesses continue to show resilience, adapting to changing circumstances. Platforms like Forward Summit provide essential spaces for collaboration and growth, reshaping perceptions of Indigenous business from underrepresented to key economic contributors.

As Indigenous businesses drive innovation, sustainability, and ethical practices, investing in their success is crucial for Canada's economic future. Learn more about the rise of Indigenous business and its impact: 

https://lnkd.in/gi_Ddpeh

#IndigenousBusiness #EconomicGrowth #Indigenomics #ForwardSummit #SustainableBusiness #Reconciliation #SelfDetermination #CanadaEconomy #IndigenousLeadership #Innovation #InclusiveGrowth #SupportIndigenousEntrepreneurs #EconomicOpportunity

title: #cop16 #cop16 #cop29 #colombia #indigenouspeoples #landback #landrights‚Ä¶ | Melissa Jun Rowley
description:
As my friend and brilliant colleague Hania Othman said to me during COP16 Colombia, our global climate conferences need change management. The results of COP29 Azerbaijan have definitely compounded this idea. It‚Äôs challenging lately to walk away from these global conveneings with clear key takeaways. 

At these events, many people ask questions like ‚ÄúWhat does is it mean to truly stand in solidarity with the communities most impacted by climate change and biodiversity loss?‚Äù To get some much-needed insight, I interviewed three Indigenous leaders from the Amazon who were invited to speak at #COP16, but not included in any of the negotiations among the organizers and governments to finance solutions‚Äîdespite the fact that Indigenous peoples steward 80% of the world‚Äôs biodiversity. Here‚Äôs what my interviewees had to say.

Thank you, for your insights, Russell Armstrong
@alexandra.narvaez.oficial @justin_piaguage and Wider Guauramag üôè 

https://lnkd.in/gvQHB2Yn

Thanks for publishing, Terry Slavin Liam Dowd Reuters Events Sustainable Business.

title: #indigenousentrepreneur #indigenous #bookkeeper #entrepreneur #scalingup‚Ä¶ | Carrie Lamb
description:
As an Indigenous entrepreneur, I‚Äôve learned a hard but liberating truth: I can‚Äôt‚Äîand shouldn‚Äôt‚Äîbe good at everything.  

When I started Sacred Workplaces, I wore every hat: Founder, marketer, salesperson, and bookkeeper. But as we‚Äôve grown, so have the administrative demands‚Äîand trying to do it all is burning me out (and honestly, my bookkeeping was‚Ä¶ not my sacred work üòÖ).  

So today, I‚Äôm dismantling the shame around asking for help. I‚Äôm thrilled to announce we‚Äôve partnered with CloudCPA LLP to handle our bookkeeping! AND how cool is it that Rachel Brinac, CPB (who‚Äôs helping me) just won this cool award. Making me feel even more cared for as an entrepreneur.

This isn‚Äôt a failure‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic upgrade. By letting go of tasks that aren‚Äôt in my zone of genius, I free up energy to focus on what truly moves the needle: serving our clients and growing our impact.  

Because scaling isn‚Äôt about doing more‚Äîit‚Äôs about leading better. And sometimes, that starts with admitting, This isn‚Äôt my strength‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs okay.

#IndigenousEntrepreneur #Indigenous #Bookkeeper #Entrepreneur #ScalingUp #ThursdayVibes #Thursday
#EntrepreneurLife #DelegateToElevate #NoShameInTheSupportGame #Leadership

CloudCPA LLP Rachel Brinac, CPB

title: #indigenousentrepreneur #housingsolutions #inspectorinabox #communityfirst‚Ä¶ | Stan Knight | 13 comments
description:
Being an Indigenous entrepreneur comes with incredible purpose ‚Äî but also some tough realities.

Lately, I‚Äôve been reflecting on the challenge of trying to connect with Indigenous leadership and housing decision-makers.

It‚Äôs a delicate balance:

- Cold calling feels intrusive
- Repeated emails feel like noise
- Unannounced or unscheduled visits can feel pushy or even disrespectful ‚Äî and that‚Äôs something I never want to risk, especially knowing how busy and stretched leadership already is
- And pushing too hard can feel like I‚Äôm disrespecting the very values I was raised with ‚Äî because in our culture, persistence without relationship can come off as pressure, not partnership

But I believe deeply in what I‚Äôm offering ‚Äî especially my Inspector in a Box program and broader consultancy services. These aren‚Äôt just products ‚Äî they‚Äôre community-led solutions designed to support Nations in building housing capacity, accessing funding, and creating self-sufficiency.

So how do we get in front of the right people without losing our cultural integrity?

This post isn‚Äôt just a reflection ‚Äî it‚Äôs a genuine ask to my network:
- Indigenous entrepreneurs ‚Äî how do YOU break through respectfully?
- How do you connect with leadership in a way that builds trust, honours their time, and still gets your work seen?

I‚Äôd love to hear what‚Äôs worked for you. Let‚Äôs support each other in building business in a good way.

#IndigenousEntrepreneur #HousingSolutions #InspectorInABox #CommunityFirst #RespectfulBusiness #FirstNationsLeadership #ReconciliationInAction #EconomicEmpowerment #ForUsByUs #IndigenousBusinessNetwork | 13 comments on LinkedIn

title: #energytransition #cleanenergy #indigenomics #gridmodernization‚Ä¶ | Don Richardson
description:
This week I had the honour to fill in for Chief Kelly LaRocca of the Mississaugas of Scugog Island First Nation (MSIFN) in a panel discussion titled "Energy Grids and Storage ‚Äì Investing in a Cleaner Future" sponsored by the Globe and Mail in partnership with Indigenous Clean Energy (ICE). 

Ontario's energy project growth is happening at a pace we have never seen, and First Nations like MSIFN are at the epicenter. Moderator Matt McClearn from the Globe and Mail's Energy, Natural Resources and Environment Team focused on the challenges and solutions for the energy transition, including the rapid growth of First Nation investments and co-development of significant projects. I am proud of our work at MSIFN through Minogi to accelerate clean energy investments with our First Nation and private sector partners with new and creative investment solutions.

We had an informative discussion with co-panelists Jason Rioux, Chief Development Officer of NRStor Inc., and Simmer Anand, Senior Manager, Indigenous Relations¬†of Hydro One. Thanks to the Globe and Mail (Lisa Wichmann) and ICE (James Jenkins) for creating the stage for this important conversation. 
#EnergyTransition #CleanEnergy #Indigenomics #GridModernization 
#IndigenousPartnerships #Sustainability

title: #indigenousscholarships #educationequity #stoppretendians‚Ä¶ | Mason Ducharme | 16 comments
description:
üì¢ Calling for a Change: Strengthening Verification for Indigenous Scholarships

Over the past 15 years, I suspect that over $1,000,000 of Indigenous-specific post-secondary scholarships and bursaries have been accessed by pretendians. This misuse highlights a significant flaw in the current self-identification process for some scholarships, which often requires no documentation to prove Indigenous identity.

Many post-secondary institutions and private sector businesses allow applicants to self-identify as Indigenous without requiring any proof. In contrast, Indigenous organizations such as the National Indian Brotherhood Trust, Chief Joe Mathias, and Lilwat Nation mandate documentation like a status card or a community letter.

Having been in post-secondary education since 2010, I‚Äôve observed that only about 20% of recipients of Indigenous scholarships or bursaries seemed authentically Indigenous, explicitly sharing their community, language, and culture. The remaining 80%, often vaguely identifying as M√©tis without specifying their community, appeared to exploit the self-identification process, thereby diverting much-needed financial support from genuinely Indigenous students.

The case of the Gill twins is a notable example of this exploitation going unpunished, and I believe there are many more cases out there. It‚Äôs clear that the self-identification process is flawed and primarily benefits pretendians.

We must eliminate self-identification for Indigenous scholarships to ensure that resources dedicated to Indigenous Peoples are used to close the socioeconomic gap for those who truly need and deserve it.

#IndigenousScholarships #EducationEquity #StopPretendians #AuthenticityMatters | 16 comments on LinkedIn
