title: #10towatch #indigenomics #telus #indigenousbusinesses‚Ä¶ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D
description:
‚ÄúConnectivity is the foundation of our reconciliation strategy. We know that reliable access to technology supports Indigenous Peoples‚Äô access to education, career opportunities, healthcare, and social support. TELUS  is committed to bringing connectivity to more Indigenous communities working closely with Indigenous governments and organizations, along with provincial and federal governments,‚Äù shares Marissa Nobauer, Director of Reconciliation, Community Engagement and External Relations.

Today we are shining a spotlight on TELUS, who is recognized as a distinguished recipient on the 2023 Indigenomics  #10TOWATCH List.

TELUS is taking significant strides in supporting Indigenous communities through their multi-faceted reconciliation strategy. Their reconciliation strategy is co-designed with Indigenous communities, focusing on fostering relationships grounded in Indigenous Ways of Knowing and supporting Indigenous Youth and communities.

Here's a glimpse of their initiatives:

‚Ä¢	Connectivity: Providing high-speed internet access to over 197 Indigenous communities and aiming to connect 20 more Indigenous lands, recognizing its crucial role in education, healthcare, and economic opportunities.
‚Ä¢	Investing in Indigenous Businesses: Striving for 7.5% investment in Indigenous-owned businesses by 2026 through their Pollinator Fund and actively increasing procurement spending with them.
‚Ä¢	Empowering Indigenous Women: Expanding their Mobility for Good program to support Indigenous women facing violence.

TELUS' dedication to Indigenous empowerment shines through their initiatives. 

Learn more about their impactful work at: https://lnkd.in/e2YEnaqu


#Indigenomics #TELUS #Indigenousbusinesses #Indigenousprosperity #IndigenousLeaders #Economicreconciliation #Indigenouseconomy #100billiondollarIndigenouseconomy

title: #esg #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community #tahltan #mining‚Ä¶ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D | 51 comments
description:
Today marks my last official day with Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC). It has been an incredible journey with some amazing progress made in a very short period of time. 

Key accomplishments that stand out for me:

- Bringing an amazing Sr. Leadership team together. The best I have ever had the honour of working with.

- Building out the drivers license, mentorship and Heavy Equipment Operators (HEO) programs to help our members and employees into cool jobs and advancing in their perspective careers.

- Revamping the safety program with a significant shift in safety culture and the roadmap to achieving COR certification. 

- Significant advancement for finance and accounting through outsourced payroll with an online tool to enhance employee value, shift in fiscal year end to improve reporting for the shareholder and a plan to go from a review to an audit.  

- Shift in construction delivery from time and materials into fixed bids. Becoming the general contractor for the TIA at Red Chris mine site and a refreshed fleet with a progressive maintenance program. 

- A focus on employee experience through the first employee survey (we did 2 to date), enhanced compensation and benefits, employee recognition program and exit interviews. 

- Enhanced communication plan with a brand refresh, 2 comprehensive reports per year, rich social media program and regular community engagement. 

I want to thank all of the dedicated TNDC employees. An amazing Sr. Leadership team.  A caring board of directors. A supportive community. Excellent industry and business partners that have supported us through our journey to date. 

Much awesomeness has been achieved and the journey is far from over. TNDC is growing and quickly being a national leader. 

Proud to be a small part of it all. 

Meduh (Thank you)!!!

Here are some of my favourite pictures over the last couple of years that I think captures the journey nicely.

Anna-May St. Amand, CPA, CA, CFE Colleen Cashin Rob McPhee Jamie Gleason Bruce Gordichuk MBA, CCMAP Calvin Carlick, BCom, MBA Nick Naugle Kody Penner Carol Danielson Newcrest Mining Newmont Corporation Seabridge Gold Inc. title: #landback #landback #indigenous #stewardship | Adina Merenlender
description:
I am 100% behind #LandBack so this is good news.
At the same time its crucial to acknowledge the irony: White settlers stole the land from Indigenous Peoples, exploited it for profit by repeatedly cutting down trees, which damaged watersheds and pushed many species to the brink of extinction. Now, as these lands become less profitable, we pat ourselves on the back for 'buying it back' only to return the land in a degraded state for healing through Indigenous Stewardship. Alas, this is where we are and #LandBack helps the entire community of life.
#Indigenous #stewardship

title: #indigenomics #decolonization #nation2nation #undrip #trc92 #fire #culture‚Ä¶ | Edgard V.
description:
An excellent publication that dives into the history, the values and the way of Indigenous business. 

It was a great evening joining Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D and members of the Indigenomics community to officially launch‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThe Rise of Indigenous Economic Power: Deconstructing Indian Act Economics.‚Äù 

Carols messaging was spot on, capturing the rise of Indigenous business that is shielded by our untrelenting resilience and cultural and cultural identity. 

The fire of Indigenous business is growing, and we as Indigenous youth will stoke the flame and raise it to new heights! 

Carols book is an instrument of power, a symbol of a narrative that is strength based. Abandondining the Indian Act‚Äôs colonial imposition. 

Meduh Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D  for your incredible commitment to creating instruments that affirm, inspire and protect our economies. 

I‚Äôll never forget the first time I glanced at the title of her first book - ‚ÄúIndigenomics.‚Äù 

I felt drawn to it, and curious as to what ‚ÄúIndigenomics‚Äù means. 

Thankfully, that same curiosity has lead me to congregate with Indigenous entrepreneurs to unlock the growth of Indigenous economies through Indigenomics IMPACT. 

Meduh, Soga Ahstay.

title: #economics #indigenomics #storytelling #canada #bookclub | Marwa Abdou
description:
Just before the holidays, Stephen Tapp, PhD gifted our team five books to offer inspiration for 2023. It didn't take long before I leapt towards Carol Anne Hilton, MBA's ‚ÄúIndigenomics ‚Äì taking a seat at the table‚Äù and finally got around to reading it this weekend. 

If Economics as a discipline is about understanding behavior around our world‚Äôs limited resources, then Indigenomics should be a field of study on its own under that umbrella. For all economic practitioners. Indigenous lands are estimated to make up around¬†20%¬†of the world‚Äôs territory, containing 80% of its remaining biodiversity (IISD). And, my guess is these are very conservative estimates as they don‚Äôt include unceded lands and territories. 

In 2011, TD Economics estimated that the size of the indigenous economy in Canada would eclipse $32 billion by 2016. That number has since grown 1.5 X ‚Äì expected to reach 100 billion by 2025. And yet, indigenous voices remain excluded (alongside numerous others).

Intersectionality is crucial in storytelling. It‚Äôs also fundamental in building a more connected understanding of the world. Making progress in today‚Äôs world requires us dig into and engage with multiple identities and perspectives simultaneously. Unfortunately, as humans we are wired to seek neatly defined boxes and checklists. It gives us a sense of security and comfort. But we‚Äôre way past the point (or at least should be) of one-dimensional invitations or assigned seats. Representation can‚Äôt be just about proportions because identities are complex and the world we live in requires agility and dynamism. So, perhaps that means that the table and the criteria around it needs to be scrapped, reimagined, and rebuilt, rather than just extended.

While it‚Äôs a broad lens, there is a lot in this work that is transferable. As Hilton says Indigenomics is about ‚Äúour relationship to ourselves, to each other, to the Earth, to our past, and our future‚Äù. 

All in all, this book didn‚Äôt disappoint. One that I wish existed (and was required) when I was a student. I hope it will have follow on work that digs further and more explicitly into the data and policy side of things.

Indigenomics Institute 

#economics #indigenomics #storytelling #canada #bookclub

title: #indigenouspeoples #indigenousbusiness #reconciliation | Mark Little | 56 comments
description:
I am deeply appreciative of being recognized by this award.¬†I have benefited greatly by so many in the Indigenous Community, who have spent time teaching me about the challenges they have faced - including residential schools, elder care, health care, water availability, education, infrastructure, economic hardships - and who have had the patience to work with me to find ways to improve the future.¬†Although we have collectively made some great progress, such as the CCAB Supply Change Initiative, TheBacha Partnership, Astisiy Partnership, Seven Lakes Oilfield Services, Pimee Well Servicing - there remains numerous Indigenous issues across our nation that make my contribution seem inadequate.¬† We can collectively do better!

Although my professional role has changed over the past few years, my heart and mind will always be supportive of the Indigenous Peoples of our nation, and I will forever be an advocate for true reconciliation.¬†Godspeed in this journey!

Although there are literally hundreds of people who have contributed to my journey, I want to personally acknowledge Mel Benson, who was a great mentor to me over several decades; and thank former Chief Jim Boucher for his never ending patience, understanding and belief in me.¬†I also wanted to acknowledge the following individuals for their enormous personal impact on my Indigenous journey and perspective:

David Bouchier
Nicole Bouchier
Former Chief Steve Courtoreille
JP Gladu  BScF  MBA  ICD.D
Roberta Jamieson
Dr.  Michael Lickers  (D.Soc.Sci.)
Chief Ray Powder
Barrie Robb
Arlene Strom
Tim Schultz
Dave Tuccaro
Chief Allan Adam
Former National Chief Shawn Atleo 
Glen Nudd

Also - congratulations to the other award recipients.  It is an honour to be recognized alongside you!
¬†
Mahsi Cho!¬†Miigwech!¬† 

Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business  #indigenouspeoples #indigenousbusiness  #reconciliation 
Hilda Letemplier   Nyden Iron-Nighttraveller  Annette Morgan 
Det'on Cho Management LP   | 56 comments on LinkedIn

description:
The expression of Indigenous value, of value creation and the distribution of wealth is expressed through ceremony and relationships within Indigenous reality. 

For thousands of years, wealth has been expressed through giving, the transaction, the distribution through ceremony and based upon the quality of recognition of relationship and connection to each other, to our environment, and to resources with respect for life at the heart of both the economy and ceremony. 

This is Indigenomics.

title: #landback #healing #indigenous #nativeamerican #sovereignty #caretakers‚Ä¶ | Sabirah Abdus-Sabur
description:
What is the Land Back Movement?

Trust me, it's not scary. The goal is not to take all the land back.

If you're serious about helping the healing process of Native peoples, then you can find a way to do so. 

In reaching out to Native communities and organizations in your area, you can find ways to assist. Or just set an intention. Land Back is a collaborative effort. Goals may differ slightly depending on the community and organization. Yet, there are generally similar overarching goals.

Check out my piece about the Land Back Movement, which also highlights recent successes made through Land Back:

https://lnkd.in/e6YWYWkS

title: #indigenousprosperity #leadership #economicempowerment #moneysmarts‚Ä¶ | Indigenous Prosperity Foundation
description:
Last week on Parliament Hill, during a special reception hosted by NACCA and the Indigenous Prosperity Foundation (IPF) to launch the Money Smarts Board Game, we witnessed a deeply meaningful moment. 

In the presence of Indigenous entrepreneurs, Members of Parliament, government leaders, industry, and non-profit partners, Bobbie Racette, Chair of IPF, ceremoniously welcomed Michelle Okere, CFRE, IPF‚Äôs inaugural Executive Director, with a stunning hand-beaded medallion.

The medallion, featuring the IPF logo and a heron, was intricately crafted by Indigenous artist Amber Asp Chief. The heron, found across Turtle Island, symbolizes good fortune, patience, and wisdom‚Äîqualities that align with the IPF‚Äôs mission to empower Indigenous women, youth, and early-stage entrepreneurs through mentorship, funding, and resources for building thriving businesses. The golden sun in the medallion reflects abundance, hope, and stability, illuminating the path forward. Beaded motifs representing First Nations, M√©tis, and Inuit peoples reflect the diverse communities IPF is committed to supporting.

In her remarks, Bobbie Racette shared:
"This medallion is more than a gift‚Äîit‚Äôs a symbol of belonging, strength, and purpose. I hope Michelle feels the unity and prosperity it embodies as she wears it and represents IPF. It reflects the journey we are on together, to uplift Indigenous communities and create new opportunities for generations to come."

This powerful ceremony‚Äîalongside the launch of the Money Smarts Board Game‚Äîwas a reminder of the impact that can be achieved when entrepreneurs, leaders, and partners come together. With Michelle‚Äôs leadership and the unwavering support of those in the room, we look forward to advancing Indigenous prosperity across the country.
Congratulations, Michelle Okere, and thank you to everyone who stands with us in this important work! 

#IndigenousProsperity #Leadership #EconomicEmpowerment #MoneySmarts #IndigenousEntrepreneurs #IndigenousWomen #Mentorship #IPF #ParliamentHill

Relay Tangie, CPA, FCCA Jennifer M Sloan Abdullah Snobar Shannin Metatawabin ICD.D NACCA Keith Matthew Sharon Redsky Mastercard Foundation ADAAWE HUB

title: #fostercaretoceo #resilience #indigenousentrepreneur #afrofacts‚Ä¶ | Natasha Delany BA, MBA
description:
Grateful for the opportunity to share my story with Lillah Penddah  of AfroFacts‚Äîa platform dedicated to education, awareness, and empowerment.

In this interview, I open up about my path from foster care to CEO, navigating years of survival through domestic violence, addiction, and abuse, and ultimately stepping into leadership, entrepreneurship, and impact.

Lillah‚Äôs own journey of building AfroFacts resonates deeply. Her commitment to education and breaking barriers in Black history education is inspiring, and I‚Äôm honored to be part of this conversation.

Stay tuned for the interview! I hope it inspires others who have faced adversity to know that transformation and success are possible.

#FosterCareToCEO #Resilience #IndigenousEntrepreneur #AfroFacts #Leadership #SurvivorToLeader

title: Indigenomics by DESIGN | Indigenomics
description:
"I love the concept of Indigenomics which talks about the actual metrics, design, and research for understanding Indigenous economic strength and development. 

We need to tell this new success story and outline the needs in responding to this emerging growing economy. 

Indigenomics is an economic platform to connect to the GDP, identify targets, create collective actions that support wealth generation within our communities. $100 billion Indigenous economy - that is the number we need to be paying attention to." - Clint Davis

Indigenomics invites dialogue, and thought provoking insight into the possibility of the Indigenous relationship both in Canada and beyond. It explores the pathway of the threshold of the Indigenous relationship and modern economies. 

Join us next week for Indigenomics in ACTION to garner the essential tools and knowledge required to be active partners in our collective response to advancing the 100 Billion Indigenous economy.

title: #latinoentrepreneur #indigenousentrepreneur #diversebusiness‚Ä¶ | Ray Nu√±ez | 17 comments
description:
I‚Äôm beyond honored to be heading to the The Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth for the Building a Successful Diverse Business program, thanks to the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce (USHCC) for the opportunity and nomination.

As a Latino and Indigenous entrepreneur, I know what it‚Äôs like to build something from the ground up without a playbook. No generational wealth, no insider connections‚Äîjust a vision, a lot of grit, and a commitment to creating something bigger than myself.

This program isn‚Äôt just about making Nu√±ez, The People's Agency and DobleImpact stronger. It‚Äôs about ensuring that diverse businesses don‚Äôt just survive but thrive. Because when we succeed, we open doors for others, we shift industries, and we prove‚Äîagain and again‚Äîthat we belong.

To every entrepreneur out there doing the hard work: Keep going. Keep building. Keep betting on yourself. The doors weren‚Äôt made for us, but that‚Äôs never stopped us before.

Let‚Äôs get to work.

title: #indigenomics #indigenomics10towatch #indigenousprosperity‚Ä¶ | Indigenomics
description:
The Indigenomics Institute is thrilled to highlight the First Nations Bank of Canada, a distinguished recipient of the Indigenomics 10 to Watch 2024 Award!

Established in 1996, First Nations Bank of Canada (FNBC) is the only Indigenous-owned Schedule 1 bank in the country. Bill Lomax, CEO, emphasizes the bank‚Äôs unique position in the financial sector. "We‚Äôre part of the financial aspect of nation-building," he explains. The bank doesn‚Äôt just offer generic services; instead, it works closely with Indigenous communities to understand and meet their specific needs. FNBC prides itself on tailoring solutions to the priorities of the nations it serves, which distinguishes it from larger commercial banks. 

Beyond financing, FNBC also plays a crucial role in helping Indigenous communities manage their financial assets. It works closely with First Nations on trust management, supporting communities as they manage settlements and other financial resources in a sustainable way. This is Indigenomics in action.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gs69-i9d

#Indigenomics #Indigenomics10towatch #Indigenousprosperity #Economicreconciliation #Indigenousbusiness

A partnership set to redefine the landscape of innovation and economic empowerment for Indigenous communities globally.
MOVE37XR, a leader in advanced technologies, is bringing its expertise to the Global Centre of Indigenomics, fostering innovation, sustainability, and Indigenous economic growth. 

Together, we aim to create an inclusive and thriving ecosystem that embraces the rich tapestry of Indigenous knowledge and the limitless possibilities of technological advancement.

This collaboration is a commitment to shaping a future where Indigenous communities lead in the realms of technology, economics, and sustainability. We believe that by merging tradition with innovation, we can unlock unprecedented opportunities and drive positive change on a global scale.

"Indigenomics" takes you on a captivating journey, unraveling the intricate web of Indigenous economies. Carol Anne Hilton masterfully intertwines traditional knowledge with modern economic principles, offering a unique perspective on how Indigenous communities can harness their strengths to drive sustainable economic development.

Overview
Indigenomics lays out the tenets of the emerging Indigenous economy, built around relationships, multigenerational stewardship of resources, and care for all. Highlights include:

‚Ä¢	The ongoing power shift and rise of the modern Indigenous economy
‚Ä¢	Voices of leading Indigenous business leaders
‚Ä¢	The unfolding story in the law courts that is testing Canada's relationship with Indigenous peoples
‚Ä¢	Exposure of the false media narrative of Indigenous dependency
‚Ä¢	A new narrative, rooted in the reality on the ground, that Indigenous peoples are economic powerhouses.

title: #theatrewithpurpose #indigenousstories #landback #companyonetheatre | Carl Howell
description:
I recently had the pleasure of attending Company One Theatre‚Äôs latest production, ‚ÄúHaunted,‚Äù and I was impressed by both the performance and its profound message. This Indigenous horror-comedy, written and directed by Tara Moses  tells the story of siblings Ash and Aaron, who have been haunting their former home for two decades. Through humor and compelling storytelling, the play delves into themes of Indigenous land rights and the Land Back movement, prompting audiences to reflect on our relationship with the land and Native communities.  

Company One Theatre consistently brings thought-provoking plays and educational events to our community, fostering important conversations around social change. I highly encourage everyone to explore their upcoming events and become engaged with their impactful work. Experiences like ‚ÄúHaunted‚Äù not only entertain but also challenge us to think deeply about pressing societal issues.

Karthik Subramanian 

#TheatreWithPurpose #IndigenousStories #LandBack #CompanyOneTheatre

description: Indigenous Prosperity Foundation | 2,121 followers on LinkedIn. Empowering and supporting the success of Indigenous entrepreneurs | The Indigenous Prosperity Foundation (IPF) is a charitable organization established by the National Aboriginal Capital Corporations Association (NACCA) and Indigenous Financial Institutions across Canada. IPF's mission centres on fostering success and empowerment among underserved Indigenous women, youth, and early-stage entrepreneurs across Canada by providing training, mentorship, access to technology, internet and seed grants to ensure accessibility and equity while building capacity within the Indigenous economic development ecosystem. Learn more and get involved at indigenousfoundation.ca.

title: #indigenousjurisdiction #indigenousprosperity #oecd | Dawn Madahbee Leach
description: Indigenous people globally have so much in common and so much to share.  I participated in the OECD Mining Cities and Regions Event in Karratha, Australia, located along the Northwest coast of the country. Dialogue pointed out that Trillions of dollars are generated through mineral extraction from the traditional territories of Indigenous People, but the communities alongside these developments remain in poverty and they generally have not had a say in these developments.  As one participant pointed out, in one mining region ‚Äúyou have 2km long trains where each carriage has $2 million worth of iron ore for export, alongside poverty and disadvantage in the predominantly Indigenous communities‚Äù. This needs to change and hopefully, events such as this where Indigenous People‚Äôs have a strong voice and as we exercise our legal jurisdiction, changes will be made. #IndigenousJurisdiction #IndigenousProsperity #OECD

title: #landback | Kari Nolasco
description:
I am my ancestors‚Äô wildest dreams.

I am successful not because of my degree, job, or talents. 

I am successful because their spirit carried me through every moment I thought I had nothing left in me to fight. 

I am made from passed down generations of inherent wisdom, knowledge, and loving kindness.

I am their wildest dreams for no other reason than the fact that I am 

still 

here. 

This weekend, may our community eat and gather intentionally, reflecting on our ancestors and their lands which we occupy.

#landback

title: #indigenomics #investments #indigenousbusiness | Paul Lacerte (Gilam Giloh), OBC
description:
Teh Beh Mussi Cho (Thank you from the bottom of my heart) for the good medicine that is being shared with our People through this Fund and the investments it will enable.  This milestone represents our shared effort to shift the economic paradigm towards reconciliation, love and healing and I am deeply honoured to be on that journey with our team at Raven Capital, with each of our investors, and with all the incredible Indigenous Founders that we invest in.  By working together, we are implementing Article 3 of the UN DRIP and we are implementing the spirit and intent of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) Calls to Action.  Deepest gratitude.

title: #indigenous #indigenousbusiness #sustainability #climateaction | John Stackhouse
description:
A thoughtful presentation from ‚Å¶‚Ä™Hydro One CEO David Lebeter at the First Nations Major Projects Coalition in Vancouver. He thanked Indigenous elders for waiting for him to ‚Äúcatch up‚Äù in his understanding of our country‚Äôs true history ‚Äî something many of us also need to be grateful for.

The utility is on an impressive path that deserves more national attention. Among its policies:

‚Äî a 50% equity option for Indigenous nations partnering in transmission lines 
‚Äî 20% of donations go to Indigenous communities
‚Äî 5% of capital is aimed at Indigenous partners 
‚Äî new HR strategies for hiring and advancement

Reconciliation in action.

#indigenous #indigenousbusiness #sustainability #climateaction

description:
Thank You for Joining us at Indigenomics IMPACT 2025
From all of us at the Indigenomics Institute ‚Äî thank you for your powerful presence and support at IMPACT 2025. Held at the H.R. MacMillan Space Centre, this gathering brought together Indigenous leaders, innovators, and changemakers from across the country to advance Indigenous Economic Reconciliation.

As Carol Anne Hilton shares,
‚ÄúThe rebuilding of Indigenous economies is not a theoretical act ‚Äî it is a modern reality that requires modern architecture.‚Äù
Thanks to you, that architecture is rising.

We‚Äôre excited to build on this momentum with the LIFE AT THE CENTER Festival ‚Äî coming June 2026. A visionary collaboration with MOVE37XR and the Space Centre, this event will explore Indigenous thought at the crossroads of economy, ecology, culture, and technology.

Stay with us ‚Äî the future is Indigenous.

title: #indigenomics #truth #reconciliation | Isobel Alice O'Connell
description:
Thank you Institute of Corporate Directors Vancouver Chapter and Deloitte Vancouver for hosting an informative member appreciation event on a rainy summer night. 

Thanks Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D for your fireside chat on how boards can recognise the need to set the stage on how to grow the story of Indigenous economic potential through #indigenomics and how companies can truly embrace #truth and #reconciliation. 

Indigenomics is a collective economic response to the legacy of the systemic exclusion of Indigenous peoples in Canada‚Äôs economic development. It is a platform for economic reconciliation on the balance sheet of Canada, and not being viewed as a liability.

Indigenous groups and communities have celebrated their culture and heritage on June 21 because the significance of summer solstice. National Indigenous People‚Äôs Day is also part of the month long Celebrate Canada program, which also includes Saint Jean-Baptist‚Äôs Day (June 24), Multicultural Day (June 27) and Canada Day (July 1). 

A personal insight, I am starting to see the emerging Indigenous economy best described in the words of Canada‚Äôs greatest ice hockey player, Wayne Gretzky: ‚ÄúSkate to where the puck is going, not where it has been.‚Äù

description:

title: #esg #business #criticalminerals #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness‚Ä¶ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D
description:
Enjoyed presenting with Rob McPhee at the Business Council of British Columbia Business Forum. 

We kept it short and punchy focussing on:

- The TNDC journey which requires a strong team, supportive community and industry /government support. 

- A drive towards a decarbonzed mining jurisdiction which will be the first Tier 1 carbon neutral mining jurisdiction in Canada.

- The need for Government and Industry to continue investing in Indigenous communities and businesses and the areas they reside in. Indigenous communities are often the gatekeepers for projects to move forward. Bring Indigenous communities into the opportunities in a meaningful way as true partners. 

Thank you again for Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) to present. Great crowd!!!

#esg #business #criticalminerals #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community #prosperity

title: #indigenomics #indigenomicsconference #saskatoon #canpoli #cdnpoli‚Ä¶ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D
description:
The enduring impact of colonization has significantly shaped our modern economic perspectives, leading to displacement and a persistent socio-economic gap among Indigenous peoples. However, the time has come for us to reclaim our narrative and strategically craft a future that aligns with the Indigenous economic worldview.

With the resurgence of business, entrepreneurship, and nation-building, there arises a crucial need for a dedicated space to focus on designing and healing our relationship with money.

üå± Indigenomics DESIGN: Indigenous Wealth Dynamics üå±
City: Saskatoon (venue to be announced)
Date: June 4th, 2024

This conference serves as a pivotal platform for dialogue on systematically transforming our approach to money, finance, commerce, investment, and capital markets. It is a forum for strategic healing and visionary design critical for the prosperity and sustainability of Indigenous communities.

Let's unite to forge a path towards a future where prosperity is deeply rooted in our cultural heritage, guided by Indigenous wisdom, and propelled by strategic innovation.

For Sponsor & Partner opportunities, please contact us at info@indigenomics.com
Subscribe to our newsletter for exclusive updates: https://tr.ee/SVKdZdWv8A

#Indigenomics #IndigenomicsConference #Saskatoon #Canpoli #Cdnpoli #IndigenomicsConference2024 #Sponsoropportunities #IndigenousBusinesses #Indigenouseconomy

title: #economicreconciliation #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community‚Ä¶ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D | 11 comments
description:
Over the last year Tlicho Government has been forming a relationship with Fortescue an Australian mining company that prides itself on its environmental stewardship and Indigenous partnerships. Late last year I had the opportunity to travel to Australia with the Tlicho Chiefs to tour some of Fortescue‚Äôs operations and to meet with various Indigenous groups that Fortescue works with throughout their operations. It was truly an inspiring trip with a great company that lives and breathes its values. 

Earlier this week while at the AME Roundup show Tlicho Government signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Fortescue to assist in developing the Tlicho lands for future mineral development (https://lnkd.in/gjAD8DTP). Truly a groundbreaking moment as the nation continues to move forward and develop its economic future. I for one could not be more proud to work with this group and help build a robust economy for the region. 

Congratulations Tlicho on an amazing step in your economic journey. 

#economicreconciliation #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community #mining #exploration #criticalminerals #AME #roundup #NWT #yellowknife | 11 comments on LinkedIn

title: #nativesovereignty #landback #indigenousdata #foodsovereignty‚Ä¶ | Native Lands Advocacy Project
description:
Access to water data is essential.

For Native producers, access to timely, accurate water data can mean the difference between resilience and risk. That‚Äôs why the Native Lands Advocacy Project (NLAP) has developed a comprehensive suite of tools to support informed decision-making, sustainable agricultural planning.

Our tools are free, open-access, and specifically designed to meet the unique needs of Native land stewards and producers.

üíß Key resources include:
üõ∞Ô∏è Surface Waters on Native Lands
üåßÔ∏è Precipitation Projections & Winter Trends
üí¶ Agricultural Water Stress Viewer
üåä Groundwater Data Explorer
üî¨ Water Quality Dashboards ‚Äì pH, Hypoxia, Pesticides, Temperature
üåâ Culvert Condition Viewer
üìà Elevation Profile Explorer

These tools are built to empower Indigenous-led planning and advocacy ‚Äî because data sovereignty is land sovereignty.

Start exploring: https://loom.ly/9N7ft4A
